{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14334,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mikania scandens, commonly known as climbing hempvine, prefers consistently moist soil. It thrives best in well-draining soils that are kept damp to the touch but not waterlogged. Regular watering is important, especially during dry spells, to maintain the moisture level. However, take care to avoid overwatering, as this can lead to root rot. Monitoring the top inch of the soil and watering when it feels dry can be an effective way to ensure adequate hydration without overwatering the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Climbing hempvine (Mikania scandens) thrives in environments where it can receive full sun to partial shade. It grows best with at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, it might benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent the leaves from scorching. This balance helps the plant maintain vibrant foliage and promotes optimal flowering. If grown indoors, placing it near a south-facing window can help meet its sunlight requirements."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mikania scandens is key to managing its vigorous growth and keeping it under control. It's best to prune in early spring before the growing season begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to encourage new growth. You can trim back the plant to the desired size, cutting above a leaf node to promote bushiness. Regular maintenance pruning can help prevent the plant from becoming invasive and ensure that it remains healthy and attractive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"climbing hempvine","description":"Mikania scandens is a species of flowering plant in the aster family, Asteraceae. Its common names include climbing hempvine, climbing hempweed, and louse-plaster. It is native to the eastern and central United States, its distribution extending into Tamaulipas in Mexico. Reports of its presence in Ontario in Canada are erroneous. It is an introduced and invasive species on many Pacific Islands and in parts of southern Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["climbing hempvine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Mikania scandens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14932,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Codiaeum variegatum, commonly known as croton, prefers to be kept evenly moist. Water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry; this typically means watering every 1-2 weeks, but it can vary depending on climate and humidity. It's important not to let the soil dry out completely or become waterlogged. During the growing season, in spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently. Reduce watering in the winter. To maintain humidity, mist the leaves regularly or place the pot on a tray with pebbles and water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Codiaeum variegatum thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, which helps it maintain its vibrant leaf colors. Ideally, place it near an east or west-facing window where it can receive ample light without being in direct sunlight too long, as this may cause leaf burning or fading. If placed indoors, ensure it gets at least 4-6 hours of filtered light daily. In lower light conditions, the colors may dull and growth could slow. If moving a croton from indoors to outdoors, acclimate it gradually to prevent shock."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Codiaeum variegatum mainly involves removing dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthy growth and maintain its shape. This can be done throughout the year, but the best time is during the plant’s active growing season in spring or early summer. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts close to the stem. Regular pruning also helps the plant grow bushier and fuller by encouraging branching. Additionally, pinch off the growing tips if you wish to control the size of the croton or encourage a denser growth habit."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Variegated Croton","description":"Codiaeum variegatum (garden croton or variegated croton; syn. Croton variegatum L.) is a species of plant in the genus Codiaeum, which is a member of the family Euphorbiaceae. It is native to Indonesia, Malaysia, Australia, and the western Pacific Ocean islands, growing in open forests and scrub. It is an evergreen shrub growing to 3 m (9.8 ft) tall and has large, thick, leathery, shiny evergreen leaves, alternately arranged, 5–30 cm (2.0–11.8 in) long and 0.5–8 cm (0.20–3.15 in) broad. The inflorescences","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Variegated (combinations of green, yellow, red, orange)"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Indonesia","Malaysia","Australia","Western Pacific Ocean islands"],"other_name":["Variegated Croton"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Mealybugs","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Codiaeum variegatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15030,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rumex verticillatus prefers consistently moist to wet soils, making it important to keep the soil around this plant adequately watered. It thrives in areas that do not dry out completely. Regular watering is essential, especially during dry spells or hot summer months, to maintain the moisture level. However, it is important to ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging, as overly saturated soil can lead to root rot. During its active growth period in spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently, reducing frequency in colder months when the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rumex verticillatus grows best in partial to full sun. It is versatile and can tolerate various light conditions, but for optimal growth and flowering, a spot with 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily is ideal. In its natural habitat, it often thrives in open water meadows, which suggests a preference for some level of sun exposure. However, it can also adapt to partially shaded areas, though this may reduce its flowering capacity. Ensure that even in lower light conditions, the plant receives dappled or indirect sunlight to aid in its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rumex verticillatus is generally minimal but can be beneficial to encourage a healthy structure and remove dead or damaged foliage. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Deadhead any spent flowers to prevent unwanted self-seeding, as this plant can proliferate easily. If the plant becomes too tall or leggy, trim back the stems to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage bushier growth. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make your cuts to minimize stress on the plant and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"swamp dock","description":"Rumex verticillatus is a flowering plant species in the family Polygonaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["swamp dock"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Rumex verticillatus"],"soil":["Wet","Rich","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14732,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Prunus serrulata, commonly known as the Japanese cherry tree, prefers moderate watering. It's essential to ensure that the soil remains consistently moist but never waterlogged. During its growing season in spring and early summer, water the tree thoroughly once or twice a week, depending on rainfall and soil drainage. Make sure the top couple of inches of soil dry out before the next watering. In the fall and winter, reduce watering frequency as the tree enters dormancy. Be cautious of overwatering, as it can lead to root rot, especially in areas with poor drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus serrulata thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. This sun exposure encourages healthy growth and abundant flowering. Partial shade can be tolerated, particularly in hotter climates, but optimal growth and bloom may be reduced. When planting in an area, consider choosing a spot that provides adequate morning sunlight and protection from harsh afternoon rays to avoid leaf scorch. Ensure the cherry tree has plenty of space to grow unrestricted, as good sunlight access is essential for robust blooms and overall plant vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Prunus serrulata should primarily occur in late winter or early spring, before new growth starts, though light pruning can be performed in summer. Focus on removing any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain the tree's shape and health. Pruning encourages air circulation, sunlight penetration, and new growth. Avoid severe pruning, as it can stress the tree. For the best bloom display, don't prune in early spring or late summer, as this can remove buds for the following year's flowers. Generally, avoid pruning once the tree has matured unless absolutely necessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese Cherry","description":"Prunus serrulata or Japanese cherry, also called hill cherry, oriental cherry or East Asian cherry, is a species of cherry native to China, Japan, Korea and India, and is used for its spring cherry blossom displays and festivals. Current sources consider it to be part of a species complex with P. jamasakura and P. leveilleana, which have been reduced to synonyms.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Japan","China","Korea"],"other_name":["Japanese Cherry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Mites","Canker","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation","Grafting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Prunus serrulata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15229,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solidago nemoralis, commonly known as gray goldenrod, prefers well-drained soil and is fairly drought-tolerant. Water young plants regularly to help them establish a strong root system, especially during dry spells. Once established, these plants require minimal watering, often thriving with just the natural rainfall. Overwatering can lead to root rot as they do not like standing water. Focus on providing deep watering sessions to promote healthier roots rather than frequent, shallow watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solidago nemoralis thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, the blooms may not be as prolific, and the plant might become leggy reaching for more light. Ensure it is planted in a spot where it receives ample sunlight, especially in the morning, to maintain a compact growth form and promote abundant flowering during the blooming season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Solidago nemoralis in late fall or early spring to encourage new growth and to maintain a tidy appearance. Cutting back the stems to a few inches above the ground helps in preventing the plant from becoming too leggy or overgrown. Deadheading spent flowers throughout the blooming season can also prolong the flowering period and prevent unwanted self-seeding. Regular pruning promotes healthier plants and can also control their spread in a garden setting."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"field goldenrod","description":"Solidago nemoralis is a species of flowering plant in the aster family, Asteraceae. It is native to North America, where it is widely found in Canada (every province except Newfoundland and Labrador) and the United States (all states wholly or partially east of the Rocky Mountains). Its common names include gray goldenrod, gray-stem goldenrod, old-field goldenrod, field goldenrod, prairie goldenrod, dwarf goldenrod, and dyersweed goldenrod.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["field goldenrod"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Solidago nemoralis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14433,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solidago caesia, commonly known as blue-stemmed goldenrod, prefers moderately moist soil conditions. During its growing season, which spans from late spring to fall, ensure consistent soil moisture by watering when the top inch of soil feels dry. Avoid overwatering, as this can lead to root rot. During winter, reduce watering frequency, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between watering. It is tolerant of occasional drought once established, but regular watering will promote optimal growth and blooming. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solidago caesia thrives best in partial to full sunlight. It requires at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal flowering and growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, flowering may be reduced in heavily shaded areas. Planting it in a location with morning sun and afternoon shade can be beneficial, especially in areas with intense summer heat. Adequate sunlight encourages healthy, upright growth and vibrant blooms. In regions with moderate climates, it can also perform well in gardens with full sun exposure throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is generally minimal for Solidago caesia. In late winter or early spring, before new growth begins, remove any dead or damaged stems to maintain a tidy appearance and promote healthy growth. After flowering, you can trim back spent flower stalks to prevent self-seeding and encourage a second flush of blooms. Cutting back the plant to one-third of its height in late fall after the first frost can help prepare it for the next growing season and improve air circulation, thereby reducing the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"bluestem goldenrod","description":"Solidago caesia, commonly named blue-stemmed goldenrod, wreath goldenrod, or woodland goldenrod, is a flowering plant native to North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["bluestem goldenrod"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Solidago caesia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14832,"attracts":["Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhus copallinum, commonly known as Winged Sumac, requires moderate watering. It is quite drought-tolerant once established, so it’s important to let the soil dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can be detrimental, leading to root rot, so it’s crucial to have a well-draining soil mix to prevent waterlogging. In general, you should water deeply but infrequently, allowing the top layer of soil to dry completely before the next watering. This mimics natural conditions and encourages deep root growth. Adjust the watering frequency based on seasonal changes, providing more water during dry spells and less during rainy periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhus copallinum thrives in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade. Ideally, this plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to promote vigorous growth and vibrant fall foliage. While it can adapt to less sunny conditions, the foliage color might not be as intense, and growth may be slower. Full sun exposure helps reduce the risk of fungal infections, as it ensures good air circulation around the plant. Excessive direct sunlight can scorch its leaves, so be cautious especially during the hottest parts of the day. If grown indoors, placing it near an east or north-facing window would be ideal to ensure it receives enough light without risking overexposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Saxifraga aizoides is generally minimal, as it has a neat and compact growth habit. It’s best to remove any dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthy new growth. You can deadhead the faded flowers during and after the blooming season to promote a tidier appearance and potentially encourage prolonged blooming. In the late fall or early spring, clean up the plant by trimming away any dried or dead foliage to prepare it for the next growing season. Avoid heavy pruning as it could damage the plant's natural form and inhibit its ability to thrive."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Yellow Saxifrage","description":"Saxifraga aizoides, yellow mountain saxifrage or yellow saxifrage, is a flowering herb and alpine plant of the genus Saxifraga.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Arctic","Northern Hemisphere"],"other_name":["Yellow Saxifrage"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Saxifraga aizoides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

The soil should be kept evenly moist, allowing the top inch to dry out between waterings. Water the plant deeply once the surface of the soil is dry to touch, ensuring that excess water drains away completely. During warmer months, increase the frequency of watering as the plant is actively growing and requires more moisture. In contrast, scale back on watering during the dormant winter months. Always check that the pot has adequate drainage holes to prevent root rot from standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Jasminum sambac thrives in full sun to partial shade, requiring at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day to produce flowers optimally. Ideally, place it in a location with bright, indirect light if intense midday sun is too harsh, as prolonged exposure can scorch the leaves. Morning sunlight is perfect to ensure growth and flowering. If growing indoors, position the plant near a south or west-facing window. Adjust the lighting conditions based on seasonal changes, ensuring adequate light during shorter, overcast days to maintain the plant's health and flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Jasminum sambac helps maintain its shape and encourages bushy growth and more blooms. The best time to prune is right after flowering or in early spring before the new growth stage. Remove dead or weak stems to allow better air circulation and sunlight penetration. Cut back long branches to the base of the plant or to a node to promote lateral growth. Regular light pruning helps control the size and shape of the plant, while heavier pruning should be done less frequently. Always use clean and sharp pruning shears to prevent plant damage and disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arabian Jasmine","description":"Jasminum sambac, the Arabian jasmine, is a species of jasmine native to a small region in the eastern Himalayas in Bhutan and neighbouring India and Pakistan. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14533,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Corymbia ficifolia, commonly known as the Red Flowering Gum, prefers well-drained soils and is somewhat drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant regularly during the first growing season to establish a deep, extensive root system. During periods of extreme heat or drought, occasional deep watering is beneficial to maintain health. Once the tree matures, reduce watering frequency, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions, as overwatering can lead to root rot. It's essential to keep young trees consistently moist but avoid soggy conditions to ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Corymbia ficifolia thrives best in full sun locations, where it receives at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. Adequate sunlight is crucial for healthy growth and abundant flowering. This tree is well-suited to sunny gardens but can also tolerate partial shade, though it may result in fewer flowers. If planting in a spot with limited sun, ensure the location is still bright and that the tree is not shaded for extended periods. Such conditions will help maintain its vibrant blooms and overall health, making it a striking focal point in any landscape."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Corymbia ficifolia is essential to develop a strong structure and maintain an attractive shape. Typically, pruning is done in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Start by removing any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Focus on shaping the tree by selectively cutting back branches to encourage a well-balanced canopy. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the tree. Remember that light, regular pruning is more beneficial than infrequent, severe cuts to keep the tree healthy and attractive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Red-flowering gum","description":"Corymbia ficifolia, commonly known as the red flowering gum, Albany red flowering gum and the Albany redgum, (previously known as Eucalyptus ficifolia) is one of the most commonly planted ornamental trees in the broader eucalyptus family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Red-flowering gum"],"pest_susceptibility":["Myrtle rust"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Corymbia ficifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Always use clean and sharp tools to minimize damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Catclaw Briar","description":"Mimosa nuttallii, the Nuttall's sensitive-briar, catclaw brier or sensitive brier, is a herbaceous perennial legume in the subfamily Mimosoideae native to the central United States. Ideally, it should receive morning sunlight followed by shade in the hotter part of the day. This plant naturally grows in woodland environments, so it appreciates filtered sunlight or dappled shade, which replicate its native habitat. In extremely hot regions, too much direct sunlight can lead to scorched leaves. Providing it with some shade during peak sunlight hours will help maintain healthy, vibrant foliage and ensure a robust blooming phase."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Spigelia marilandica is generally minimal and can be done to maintain the plant's shape and encourage denser growth. After the flowering period, you may deadhead spent blooms to prevent seed formation and prolong the bloom period. If the foliage becomes untidy or damaged by pests, trim back selectively. Each year, it's best to cut back the stems to the ground in late autumn, after flowering ends, to make way for fresh spring growth. Regular removal of dead or yellowing leaves helps maintain aesthetics and plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"woodland pinkroot","description":"Spigelia marilandica, the woodland pinkroot or Indian pink, is a perennial wildflower in the Loganiaceae family that is used as ornamental plant. It will grow 30–61 cm (1–2 ft) high with a spread of 15–46 cm (0.5–1.5 ft).","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["woodland pinkroot"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Spigelia marilandica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Reduce watering in the fall and winter months when the plant is not actively growing, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between watering sessions to mimic its natural growing conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Saxifraga cernua thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, mimicking its natural habitat where it receives filtered light. Direct midday sun should be avoided as it can lead to leaf burn. If growing in a less sunny indoor location, supplemental lighting can be beneficial. Ensuring adequate light helps maintain healthy foliage and encourages consistent blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Saxifraga cernua is generally minimal since it is a small, compact plant. Remove any dead or damaged leaves and flowers regularly to promote healthy new growth and prevent the risk of disease. Deadheading spent blooms will also help maintain the plant's appearance and encourage further flowering. It is important to handle the plant carefully during pruning to avoid damaging the tender stems. If the plant becomes too dense, thinning some of the older leaves can improve air circulation. Prune during the early spring before the plant's active growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Nodding Saxifrage","description":"Saxifraga cernua, the drooping saxifrage, nodding saxifrage or bulblet saxifrage, is a flower common all over the High Arctic. It's crucial not to overwater this plant, as it is drought-tolerant once established. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season, typically spring and early summer, provide consistent moisture to encourage blooming. However, be mindful during rainy seasons, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. It can tolerate some light shade, particularly in hotter climates, but will flower best when exposed to ample sunlight. In shadier conditions, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer blooms. Position Liatris aspera in a sunny spot in your garden for optimal growth and flowering. In regions with intense sun and high temperatures, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant, but ensure it still receives adequate light exposure overall."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Liatris aspera is relatively simple. Deadheading spent flowers can prolong blooming and tidy up the plant's appearance. In late fall or early spring, cut back the old stems to ground level to encourage new growth for the next season. This perennial doesn't require extensive pruning, but removing dead or damaged stems at any time can promote better air circulation and prevent disease. In areas with harsh winters, leaving the stems till spring can provide some seasonal interest and offer some protection to the plant's base."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"rough blazing star","description":"Liatris aspera also known as the lacerate, rough, tall or prairie blazing star is a wildflower that is found in the mid to eastern United States in habitats that range from mesic to dry prairie and dry savanna.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["rough blazing star"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Liatris aspera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When watering, it's important to ensure the soil dries out completely between waterings. However, occasional light pruning can help encourage denser growth and remove any dead or damaged branches, maintaining its health and aesthetics. When pruning, ensure to use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Florida rosemary","description":"Ceratiola is a genus of flowering plants with a single species, Ceratiola ericoides, the sand heath, sandhill-rosemary or Florida-rosemary, is a species of shrub usually included in the plant family Ericaceae, though treated by some botanists in the Empetraceae. It is the sole species in the genus Ceratiola.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["Florida rosemary"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ceratiola ericoides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15427,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Podocarpus latifolius, also known as the yellowwood, prefers moist but well-drained soil conditions. Water the plant consistently but allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. The plant is somewhat drought tolerant once established but thrives with regular watering, especially in hotter or drier periods. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure proper drainage in the pot or garden bed. During the growing season, which is typically spring through summer, increase watering frequency to promote healthy growth. In the cooler months, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Podocarpus latifolius thrives in a location that receives full sun to partial shade. Ideally, provide it with 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and foliage development. In excessively hot climates, some afternoon shade can protect it from leaf scorch. The plant is adaptable and can tolerate a range of light conditions, but not enough light can result in sparser growth. When placing indoors, ensure it gets plenty of bright, indirect sunlight near a window. Regularly rotate the plant to prevent uneven growth due to varying light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Podocarpus latifolius is not always necessary but can be done to maintain the desired shape or size and promote bushier growth. It's best to prune during the late winter to early spring, just before the new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation within the plant. For shaping, trim the tips of branches to encourage denser foliage. Avoid cutting back into old wood, as this can slow regrowth. Regular but light pruning maintains its natural form, although it can handle more substantial shaping if used as a hedge."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"real yellowwood","description":"Podocarpus latifolius (broad-leaved yellowwood or real yellowwood, Afrikaans: Opregte-geelhout, Northern Sotho: Mogôbagôba, Xhosa: Umcheya, Zulu: Umkhoba) is a large evergreen tree up to 35 m high and 3 m trunk diameter, in the conifer family Podocarpaceae; it is the type species of the genus Podocarpus.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["real yellowwood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Podocarpus latifolius"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15630,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Laelia speciosa, commonly known as the \"orquídea de mayo\" or \"mayflower orchid,\" requires careful watering to thrive. During its active growing season, water the plant thoroughly once the potting medium has nearly dried out, typically once a week. Avoid letting the roots sit in water to prevent rot. In the winter rest period, reduce watering significantly, allowing the medium to dry completely between waterings. Always use room temperature, preferably distilled or rainwater, as these orchids are sensitive to mineral buildup in tap water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Laelia speciosa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Ensure the plant receives adequate light exposure to promote flowering but avoid direct sunlight, particularly during hot afternoons, as this can scorch the leaves. Ideally, place it near an east-facing window or provide filtered light if grown outdoors. If the leaves become dark green, it may indicate insufficient light, while yellowing leaves suggest excessive light. Utilizing a sheer curtain can help diffuse sunlight if the exposure is too intense."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Laelia speciosa mainly involves cutting away any dead or yellowing leaves and flower spikes once they have completely dried. This helps to maintain the plant’s overall health and appearance. Always use sterilized cutting tools to prevent the spread of disease. Be cautious not to damage the pseudobulbs during pruning, as they store essential nutrients for the plant. Conduct pruning at the end of the bloom cycle to prepare the plant for its next growth phase."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mayflower Orchid","description":"Laelia speciosa, commonly known as the Mayflower orchid, is a species of showy orchid found in area of Mexico with high elevation of 1,400 m (4,593 ft) to 2,400 m (7,874 ft). The plant is very drought resistant and can tolerate cool to warm conditions. It blooms from summer to fall, producing fragrant flowers. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15729,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Saxifraga tricuspidata, commonly known as three-toothed saxifrage, thrives in well-draining soil and prefers moderate watering. It is adapted to rocky and mountainous habitats, meaning that it can tolerate periods of dryness between waterings. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely before the next watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it’s important to ensure that the soil is not consistently damp. During the growing season in spring and summer, slightly increase the frequency of watering, but reduce it in the winter months when the plant is less active."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant prefers a location with full sun to part shade. In more temperate climates, it does best with full sun exposure, which will enhance blooming and overall health. However, in hotter climates, partial shade can protect it from the intense afternoon sun, preventing scorch and dehydration. Ideally, provide Saxifraga tricuspidata with morning sunlight and afternoon shade for optimal growth. Ensure that your planting site or pot receives a minimum of 4-6 hours of sunlight daily. However, avoid deep shade as it may hinder the plant's flowering and cause leggy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Saxifraga tricuspidata is not often necessary but can be beneficial for maintaining a tidy appearance. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves as they appear, which helps prevent disease and encourages healthier growth. In the early spring, before new growth starts, you may lightly trim back any leggy or overgrown areas to maintain a compact shape. Deadheading spent flowers will promote a neater appearance and may encourage further blooming. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruners to avoid damaging the plant. Regularly check for any pests or disease symptoms when pruning."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Prickly Saxifrage","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Northern Hemisphere","Arctic","Subarctic","Boreal regions"],"other_name":["Prickly Saxifrage"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Saxifraga tricuspidata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If planted in containers, water whenever the top inch of the soil feels dry to ensure the roots have adequate moisture. Reduce watering during fall and winter when growth slows down, but never allow the soil to completely dry out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex brunnescens prefers dappled sunlight or partial shade, mimicking the conditions of its native woodland and moist forest habitats. If it is situated in a sunnier spot, ensure that the soil remains moist to help mitigate potential heat stress. Ideally, plant in areas that receive filtered sunlight through tree canopies or afternoon shade for optimal growth and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex brunnescens involves minimal grooming, mostly to maintain its aesthetic appeal and health. During late winter or early spring, cut back any dead or damaged foliage to the base of the plant to encourage new, healthy growth. This allows the plant to rejuvenate and maintain a tidy appearance. Be careful not to cut into any new growth emerging from the base. Regular removal of the browned or dead leaves throughout the growing season will keep the plant looking its best and prevent disease. Overall, pruning requirements are low but beneficial for vitality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Brownish Sedge","description":"Carex brunnescens, commonly known as the brownish sedge, is a species of sedge in the genus Carex.","family":null,"flower_color":"Brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Brownish Sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Carex brunnescens"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, care should be taken to avoid waterlogging as it can lead to root rot. The soil should be allowed to dry out slightly between watering sessions but not completely dry. In areas with regular rainfall, natural precipitation may be sufficient, reducing the need for supplemental watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lathyrus pratensis thrives best in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade, making it versatile for various garden settings. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and blooming. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing it with a bit of afternoon shade can prevent it from wilting due to heat stress. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering, so it's important to choose a location that allows it to soak in as much light as possible for the majority of the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Lathyrus pratensis involves mainly the removal of dead or damaged stems and spent flowers to encourage bushier growth and more prolific blooming. This is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. If you wish to control its spread or maintain a tidier shape, you can trim back some of the longer stems during the growing season. Avoid cutting back too drastically as this can affect flowering performance. Regular deadheading throughout the blooming period will help prolong the flowering season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"meadow pea","description":"Lathyrus pratensis or meadow vetchling, meadow pea and meadow pea-vine, is a perennial legume that grows to 1.2 m in height.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["meadow pea"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lathyrus pratensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Chalky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

For optimal growth, ensure that the substrate (such as a wood chip or straw bed) is consistently moist but not waterlogged. During dry periods, water lightly to maintain the right level of moisture—much like tending to a garden plant mulch. Avoid standing water, which can promote mold or rot. Additionally, misting the area can help maintain humidity, especially in drier climates or indoor settings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Stropharia rugosoannulata prefers partial shade when cultivated outdoors. In its natural settings or garden beds, it can tolerate some direct morning sunlight but should be protected from intense afternoon sun, which can dry out the substrate and harm the mycelium network. If growing indoors or in a controlled environment, use indirect light to mimic these conditions. Excessive sunlight exposure can negatively impact moisture levels, so ensuring a balance of light and shade is crucial for optimal mushroom production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning isn't typically necessary for Stropharia rugosoannulata like it is for many plants, as it is a fungus, not a plant. However, to ensure healthy mushroom growth, regularly remove any old or decaying mushrooms from the growing area. This helps prevent mold and contamination, fostering a cleaner environment for new mushrooms to sprout. Harvesting mature mushrooms promptly not only aids in cleanliness but also stimulates further growth. Remember to use clean hands or tools when handling mushrooms to avoid introducing pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wine-cap Stropharia","description":"Stropharia rugosoannulata, commonly known as the wine cap stropharia, \"garden giant\", burgundy mushroom or king stropharia (Japanese: saketsubatake), is an agaric of the family Strophariaceae found in Europe and North America, and introduced to Australia and New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Wine-cap Stropharia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Stropharia rugosoannulata"],"soil":["Loamy","Rich","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14834,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Helianthus angustifolius, also known as the Swamp Sunflower, requires regular watering to maintain optimal growth, especially during the heat of summer and in the absence of rainfall. It prefers moist to wet soils, making it ideal for areas with natural dampness or those that can be irrigated regularly. Ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged, as this can lead to root rot. During periods of drought, increase watering frequency, but always allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly to prevent overwatering. Water thoroughly at the base of the plant to encourage deep root growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Swamp Sunflowers thrive in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for robust growth and plentiful blooms. While they can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight will lead to fewer flowers and a leggier plant structure. Therefore, planting it in an area that receives unobstructed sunlight is optimal. Full sun also assists in keeping the soil warm, which is beneficial for this particular sunflower's growth cycle. Ensure that taller plants or structures do not overshadow Helianthus angustifolius to maintain its health and blooming potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helianthus angustifolius is essential to encourage a bushier growth and prevent legginess. In early spring, cut back old stems that did not survive the winter. As the plant grows, pinch back the tips in early summer to promote branching; this can be done once or twice. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continued blooming throughout the fall. After the flowering season ends, which is usually around late fall, cut back the plant to about 6 inches above the ground to tidy up the appearance and prepare it for winter dormancy. This helps in promoting vigorous growth the following spring."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"narrowleaf sunflower","description":"Helianthus angustifolius is a species of sunflower known by the common name narrowleaf sunflower or swamp sunflower. It is native to the south-central and eastern United States, found in all the coastal states from Texas to Long Island, and inland as far as Missouri. It is typically found in the coastal plain habitat (both the Atlantic and Gulf), particularly in wet areas.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["narrowleaf sunflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Helianthus angustifolius"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15730,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Diapensia lapponica, commonly known as Lapland Diapensia, requires carefully balanced water conditions. It prefers well-drained, acidic soils and should not be kept too wet, as it is susceptible to root rot in waterlogged conditions. During its growing season in spring and early summer, maintain consistent moisture, but allow the surface to dry slightly between waterings. In contrast, during periods of dormancy in the late summer and fall, reduce watering significantly. It's essential to emulate its natural alpine habitat, which offers excellent drainage and sporadic moisture from condensating mists and infrequent rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Diapensia lapponica thrives in conditions similar to its native alpine environments, requiring full sun to part shade. Ideally, it should receive several hours of direct morning sunlight, with some protection from the intense afternoon sun, which can scorch the leaves. If planting in a garden, choose a location with ample sunlight exposure or consider positioning it near a rock or structure that can provide light shade. In warmer climates, more afternoon shade may be necessary to mimic the cooler, filtered light environment typical of its natural high-altitude settings."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Diapensia lapponica is generally minimal and primarily involves removing dead or damaged leaves. This should be done in early spring before the growing season begins, or in late fall after the plant becomes dormant. Use sterile scissors or pruning shears to prevent the spread of disease. Additionally, remove spent flowers to prevent the plant from putting energy into seed production, which can encourage healthier growth. However, care should be taken not to over-prune, as Diapensia grows slowly and excessive trimming can impair its growth and overall health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Diapensia","description":"Diapensia lapponica, the pincushion plant, is a plant in the family Diapensiaceae, the only circumboreal species in the genus Diapensia, the others being mainly in the Himalaya and on mountains in southwestern China. This species likely became Circumboreal-circumpolar after it jumped to arctic habitat from North China and Russia. The most likely candidate for ancestor is a white-flowered D. purpurea (Day R.T. 2003. Diapensia on Cheju Island, South Korea and Musings on Origins. Sarracenia 11(3):29-31.) The","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Northern North America","Northern Europe","Northern Asia"],"other_name":["Diapensia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Diapensia lapponica"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15631,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Musa acuminata, commonly known as the banana plant, requires regular watering to maintain its large leaves and rapid growth. The soil should be kept consistently moist, but not waterlogged. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During the warmer growing months, you may need to water more frequently, possibly every few days, while in cooler weather, watering can be reduced. Always ensure the pot has good drainage to prevent root rot. Misting the leaves can also help in maintaining humidity, an essential factor for this tropical plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Musa acuminata thrives in bright, direct sunlight but can also tolerate partial shade. Ideally, provide it with at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day to ensure vigorous growth and fruit production. If placed indoors, consider a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample sunlight. If growing outdoors, ensure it's in a spot that receives direct sunlight for most parts of the day. However, during very hot summer months, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. Insufficient light can lead to slower growth and reduced fruit yield."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Musa acuminata involves removing dead, damaged, or diseased leaves to maintain the plant's health and appearance. It's best to use a sharp, clean pair of pruning shears to cut the old leaves back to just above the plant base. As the plant matures, it will produce suckers or 'pups'; these can be pruned to control growth or propagated to grow new plants. Regular pruning not only helps in maintaining a tidy look but also encourages healthier growth by allowing the plant to focus its energy on producing new leaves and fruit."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cavendish banana","description":"Musa acuminata is a species of banana native to Southeast Asia. Most of the modern edible dessert bananas belong to this species, although some are hybrids with Musa balbisiana. First cultivated by humans at around 8000 BC, it is one of the early examples of domesticated plants.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Yellow\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeast Asia"],"other_name":["Cavendish banana"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Suckers","Rhizomes"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Musa acuminata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15233,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Heliopsis helianthoides, commonly known as false sunflower, prefers consistent moisture but is quite drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry. During the growing season, ensure that it receives about 1 to 1.5 inches of water per week, either from rainfall or supplemental watering. Avoid overwatering, as it may lead to root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and keep the roots cool. Adjust watering in response to rainfall, temperature, and the plant's needs during different seasons."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Heliopsis helianthoides thrives in full sunlight, meaning it requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. It can tolerate partial shade, but full sun will result in the best flowering and overall vigor. In regions with very intense sun or extreme heat, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent scorching. Ensure the plant is located in a sunny spot, away from large trees or structures that might cast long shadows. If growing in containers, rotate the pots regularly to ensure even sunlight exposure on all sides."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Heliopsis helianthoides is essential to promote healthy growth and prolong blooming. Deadhead the spent flowers regularly to encourage more blooms and prevent self-seeding. In late fall or early spring, cut back the stems to a few inches above the ground to clean up the plant and encourage vigorous new growth. Removing any dead or damaged stems throughout the growing season can also improve air circulation. If the plant becomes too tall or leggy, trim the stems back lightly to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage a more compact growth habit."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"false sunflower","description":"Heliopsis helianthoides is a species of flowering plant in the family Asteraceae, known by the common names rough oxeye, smooth oxeye and false sunflower. It is native to eastern and central North America from Saskatchewan east to Newfoundland and south as far as Texas, New Mexico, and Georgia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Canada","United States"],"other_name":["false sunflower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Heliopsis helianthoides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It prefers consistently damp conditions, so regular watering is crucial, particularly during dry spells to prevent the soil from drying out completely. Ensure that the soil remains soggy but not waterlogged, as excessive standing water can cause root rot. Mulching can help retain moisture in the soil. Adjust watering frequency seasonally, with more during growth periods in spring and summer, and less in winter when the plant's growth pace reduces."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex granularis prefers partial to full shade, especially in hotter climates. Though adaptable to a variety of light conditions, it thrives best in areas that offer dappled sunlight, similar to its natural woodland edge environment. In regions with intense sunlight, providing ample shade is necessary to prevent the foliage from scorching and to maintain soil moisture levels. If grown in full sun, ensure it receives additional water to compensate for increased evaporation. Monitor the plant for signs of sun stress, such as browning tips, which indicate the need for more shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex granularis is generally not a necessity, but light trimming can enhance its appearance and health. In early spring, before the new growth begins, remove any dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthy growth. This allows air and light to reach the inner sections of the plant. If the plants become too dense or unruly, you can trim them back to maintain a tidy look. Be cautious not to cut into the crown as it can affect the plant's vigor. Deadheading is unnecessary as the plant naturally self-seeds in its habitat."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Limestone Meadow sedge","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Limestone Meadow sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Carex granularis"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14142,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dibaeis baeomyces, commonly known as \"pink earth lichen,\" requires moderate watering. Typically, lichens absorb water from the atmosphere, so maintaining a humid environment can be beneficial. If you are cultivating it indoors or in a less humid climate, ensure the substrate is moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering can be detrimental, leading to mold or rot, as lichens are adapted to draw moisture from surrounding air. Spraying the plant lightly with water during dry periods can simulate its natural habitat conditions and provide adequate hydration."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dibaeis baeomyces thrives in areas with indirect sunlight. Though it can tolerate various lighting conditions, prolonged exposure to direct sunlight can lead to dehydration and damage. Ideally, place it in locations with dappled shade or where it receives filtered light for several hours a day. Understanding its natural environment, where it is often found on shaded forest floors or rock surfaces, can help emulate suitable light conditions. Avoid placing it in dark areas for extended periods, as this can hinder its growth and vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dibaeis baeomyces is not a typical maintenance requirement since lichens generally grow slowly and do not become overgrown. Ideally, provide filtered light or dappled shade throughout the day to mimic its natural habitat. Ensuring shade during the hottest part of the afternoon will promote healthy foliage and vibrant flowering without overwhelming the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solidago flexicaulis is mainly aimed at maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. Trim the plant back in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems and to make way for new growth. As the plant finishes blooming in late summer or early fall, you can cut back spent flower stalks to tidy up its appearance. For a more controlled growth, regular deadheading during the blooming period can promote additional flowering and prevent self-seeding, which can lead to unwanted spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"broad-leaved goldenrod","description":"Solidago flexicaulis, the broadleaved goldenrod, or zigzag goldenrod, is a North American species of herbaceous perennial plants in the sunflower family (Asteraceae). It grows in a variety of habitats including mesic upland forests, well drained floodplain forests, seepage swamp hummocks, and rocky woodlands.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["broad-leaved goldenrod"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Solidago flexicaulis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After the first year, it needs little additional water beyond natural rainfall, except during prolonged dry spells. It is best to prune this plant in late winter to early spring before the new growth starts. Remove any dead or diseased branches first, then trim back the longer stems to promote a more compact form. Be cautious not to remove more than one-third of the total plant size to avoid stressing it. Regularly pruning spent flowers can also encourage additional blooms and maintain a tidier appearance throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Poverty Weed","description":"Baccharis neglecta (also known as false willow, jara dulce, poverty weed, New Deal weed, and Roosevelt weed) is a species of perennial plant from sunflower family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14639,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crataegus mexicana, or Mexican Hawthorn, prefers moderate watering. Water the plant deeply once a week during dry spells, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. Be cautious not to overwater, as it prefers well-draining soil and can suffer from excess moisture. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch, but too much shade may reduce flowering and fruit production. When planting, choose a location that ensures ample sunlight exposure to maintain a healthy, vigorous plant. Position it away from structures or taller plants that might block sunlight, ensuring its full solar gain during the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crataegus mexicana is important to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased wood. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring, before new growth starts. Focus on removing any crossing branches, suckers, or watersprouts to promote healthy structure and air circulation. Regular pruning will also help open up the center of the plant, reducing the risk of disease and encouraging an attractive growth habit. Light trimming can also be done in summer if necessary to control its size and shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tejocote","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["tejocote"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf spot","Fire blight"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Crataegus mexicana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to keep the plant evenly watered during the growing season, allowing the soil to dry slightly between watering sessions. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. During winter, reduce watering frequency, but do not let the soil completely dry out. In dry climates or during hot weather, more frequent watering might be necessary to maintain soil moisture and ensure the health of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euonymus obovatus thrives in partial to full shade, making it an excellent plant for shady garden spots. It can tolerate some morning sun, but prolonged exposure to intense afternoon sunlight may harm its foliage. If grown in partial sun, the plant may have a denser habit and more vibrant foliage. Ensure it receives enough shade, especially in hotter climates, to prevent leaf scorch. Adaptability to shaded environments makes it a versatile choice for woodland gardens or areas with dappled sunlight beneath trees."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euonymus obovatus is generally not extensive, as the plant tends to maintain a pleasing natural shape. However, light pruning in late winter or early spring can help control its spread and encourage denser growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems first. Prune to maintain the desired shape or to remove any overly long stems that disrupt its form. Pruning can also stimulate new growth, enhancing the plant’s overall health. It's advised to use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid damaging the plant during the process."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Running Strawberry-bush","description":"Euonymus obovatus, the running strawberry bush, is a trailing, woodland groundcover plant of the Celastraceae family, which is native to eastern North America in the eastern United States and southeastern Canada.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellowish-green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange to pink\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Running Strawberry-bush"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Euonymus obovatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Although it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade might slow its growth and affect its overall vigor. Providing a balance of sunlight while protecting it from extreme heat will ensure the tree's best development and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Prumnopitys taxifolia is typically minimal, as it's a slow-growing conifer that naturally maintains a neat shape. Pruning should be performed during late winter to early spring before new growth starts. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain health and aesthetics. Regular maintenance by inspecting for dead branches will help in keeping the tree healthy and attractive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mataī","description":"Prumnopitys taxifolia (mataī or black pine) is an endemic New Zealand coniferous tree that grows on the North Island and South Island. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14937,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Stachys byzantina is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. It is important to allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, especially in areas with humid climates or during rainy seasons. Water deeply but infrequently, typically once every week or two during the growing season, and reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant is not actively growing. Overwatering should be avoided as this plant is adapted to dry conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Stachys byzantina thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade, although its growth may be less vigorous and foliage less dense in shadier spots. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to maintain its characteristic silver-grey, velvety leaves and compact growth habit. In particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching. Ensuring sufficient sunlight will also help to enhance flowering and overall plant health, making it an excellent choice for sunny garden borders or rock gardens."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Stachys byzantina is relatively simple and involves removing spent flowers and any dead or damaged foliage to encourage healthy growth. It is beneficial to trim back the flower stalks once they have finished blooming to maintain the plant's compact appearance and to prevent self-seeding, which can lead to spread. In late winter or early spring, before new growth starts, a more thorough trim to neaten the plant and remove dead leaves can be performed. Regular pruning will help keep the plant tidy and encourage more vigorous growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"woolly hedgenettle","description":"Stachys byzantina (syn. S. lanata; lamb's-ear or woolly hedgenettle) is a species of Stachys, native to Turkey, Armenia, and Iran. It is cultivated over much of the temperate world as an ornamental plant, and is naturalised in some locations as an escapee from gardens. Plants are very often found under the synonym Stachys lanata or Stachys olympica.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Silver"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eastern Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["woolly hedgenettle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Stachys byzantina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its growing season, you may need to water once a week, depending on rainfall and temperature. Reduce watering in the fall as the plant enters dormancy. Trimming the tips of young plants can also help encourage branching and more flower heads. After the first frost in fall when the plant has died back, you can cut the stems down to a few inches to tidy up the garden and prepare for new growth in spring."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Stiff Sunflower","description":"Helianthus pauciflorus, called the stiff sunflower is a North American plant species in the sunflower family. It typically matures to 5-8’ tall, and can spread by root suckers to form colonies. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14339,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Kiggelaria africana, commonly known as the wild peach, prefers regular watering, especially during dry spells once established. During its initial growing period, keep the soil consistently moist but avoid waterlogging, as this can harm the plant’s roots. As a drought-tolerant species, once it is firmly established, it can withstand periods of dryer conditions. However, for optimal growth and to maintain healthy foliage, providing deep watering every couple of weeks during dry seasons is recommended. Always ensure that the plant's soil has good drainage to prevent any standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Kiggelaria africana thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day to promote robust growth and healthy flowering. If planted in an area with intense afternoon sun, providing some light shade can help prevent leaf scorching. In regions with hotter climates, partial shade during the peak sunlight hours can be beneficial. While it can tolerate some shade, reduced sunlight may impact its flowering and overall growth, making full to partial sunlight exposure ideal for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Kiggelaria africana is generally minimal, but it is beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging denser growth. Prune to remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches, ideally during late winter or early spring. This promotes healthy growth before the new season's growth spurts. Slightly regularly prune young plants to establish a strong structure. When pruning, always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and avoid any damage that could lead to disease. Remember, excessive pruning should be avoided to maintain the natural beauty and form of the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wild Peach","description":"Kiggelaria africana (also known as the wild peach or umKokoko) is a large, robust, low-branching African tree, and is currently the only accepted species in the genus Kiggelaria.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Wild Peach"],"pest_susceptibility":["Caterpillars"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Kiggelaria africana"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14737,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Spiraea japonica requires moderate watering, especially during its first growing season to establish a deep, extensive root system. Once established, it's fairly drought-tolerant. Water the plant thoroughly, letting the soil become dry to the touch in between waterings. During particularly hot and dry periods, increase the frequency of watering to maintain its vigor and health. Ensuring the soil is well-drained is crucial, as Spiraea japonica does not do well in waterlogged conditions, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spiraea japonica thrives in full sun, which means it requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to bloom optimally. This will encourage more blooms and maintain a neat appearance. You can cut back the stems by one-third to half of their length. Additionally, deadheading spent flowers can help prolong flowering and improve the plant's overall aesthetic."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Japanese Spirea","description":"Spiraea japonica, the Japanese meadowsweet, Japanese spiraea, or Korean spiraea, is a plant in the family Rosaceae. It should be watered regularly to prevent the soil from drying out completely, especially in dry seasons. However, while it does favor moisture, make sure the plant is not waterlogged as this can cause root rot. A well-draining soil mix can help prevent excess water retention. Watering should be adjusted according to environmental conditions; increase frequency during hot, dry periods and decrease during cooler, wetter months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chrysosplenium alternifolium thrives in partial to full shade, which mirrors its native growing conditions in shaded woodlands and wetlands. It is well adapted to low-light environments and should be protected from direct, harsh sunlight which can scorch its delicate foliage. If grown outdoors, placing it under the canopy of larger plants or trees can prevent excessive sun exposure. Indoors, it should be situated in a location that receives filtered or indirect sunlight, away from bright, south-facing windows."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Chrysosplenium alternifolium is generally minimal but can be beneficial for maintaining its appearance and health. Remove any dead, damaged, or yellowing leaves to encourage vigorous growth and reduce the risk of disease. Pruning should ideally occur after the flowering period to also manage the plant size and to promote new growth. If the plant becomes too bushy or crowded, thin out some of the older stems to improve air circulation and light penetration, which can invigorate the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alternate-leaved Golden Saxifrage","description":"Chrysosplenium alternifolium is a species of flowering plant in the saxifrage family known as the alternate-leaved golden-saxifrage. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15136,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Viola hastata, commonly known as the halberd-leaved yellow violet, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. It is important not to let the soil dry out completely, as this can stress the plant. Water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. It is best to water at the base of the plant to avoid wetting the foliage. During the hotter summer months, more frequent watering may be necessary to maintain the soil moisture. Ensure that the plant is not sitting in waterlogged soil to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola hastata thrives best in partial to full shade environments. It is adapted to forest floors and thus prefers dappled sunlight or morning sun with afternoon shade. Direct, harsh sunlight can scorch the leaves and inhibit healthy growth, so avoid placing it in full sun. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a north or east-facing window could work well but ensure the light exposure doesn’t get too intense. These conditions will allow the Viola hastata to maintain its vibrant foliage and prolific flowering habit."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Viola hastata is relatively simple and primarily involves deadheading and removing spent flowers to promote prolonging bloom time and improve plant appearance. Once flowering has finished, lightly trim the plant back to remove any unsightly or damaged foliage, which can help prevent diseases and encourage healthier growth. Be careful not to cut back too much foliage, as these plants need their leaves to photosynthesize effectively. Regularly checking and removing browned or dead leaves will ensure the plant remains healthy and aesthetically pleasing."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Halberd-leaved violet","description":"Viola hastata, commonly known as the halberd-leaved yellow violet, is a perennial plant in the violet family found in the eastern United States. It blooms from March to May with yellow flowers.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Halberd-leaved violet"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Viola hastata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
