{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16021,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Angelica sylvestris, commonly known as wild angelica, prefers consistently moist soil. Water the plant regularly, ensuring that the soil remains damp but not waterlogged. During hot and dry periods, increase the frequency of watering to prevent the plant from drying out. Providing a layer of mulch around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. Be careful not to let the soil dry out completely between watering sessions, as this plant thrives in moist conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Angelica sylvestris thrives in partial to full sun conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight per day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense sun. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. It's important to find a balance based on your climate: too little sun can decrease flowering, while too much can lead to wilting if water needs are not adequately met."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Angelica sylvestris can help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. It's best to prune this plant in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems at the base. If the plant starts to look unruly, cut back the stems to desired length, making sure not to remove more than one-third of the plant at a time. Deadhead spent flowers to prevent self-seeding and encourage longer flowering. However, if you desire seed production, allow some of the flowers to develop seeds."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wild Angelica","description":"Angelica sylvestris or wild angelica is a species of plant, an umbellifer, that grows about one to two and a half metres tall.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Wild Angelica"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Angelica sylvestris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15929,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Physcia stellaris, being a lichen rather than a traditional plant, does not require traditional watering like houseplants. Instead, it absorbs moisture directly from the air or rain in its natural environment. If you are growing it in a controlled environment, ensure it is kept humid, as this mimics its natural conditions. Avoid direct watering; instead, maintain humidity levels through indirect misting or using a humidifier to simulate the damp environment lichens thrive in. Ensure good air circulation and avoid excess water to prevent issues with mold or fungal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Physcia stellaris typically thrives in environments that provide diffuse or filtered sunlight rather than direct, intense sun. Lichens are often found in natural environments on tree bark or rocks where they receive dappled sunlight. If you're replicating this indoors, place your lichen in a location that receives indirect light or a few hours of morning sun. Avoid placing it in harsh, direct sunlight for extended periods, as this can dry out and damage the lichen. Striking a balance with light exposure is crucial for maintaining its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Physcia stellaris, as a lichen, generally doesn't require pruning in the way that many plants do. Instead, you may want to occasionally remove dead or damaged sections to maintain its health and appearance. This should be done gently by hand, avoiding the use of tools that could damage the delicate structure. Be careful not to disturb the living portions, as lichens can be quite sensitive to mechanical damage. Regularly inspecting your lichen for any signs of stress or decay and gently removing any affected areas can help it stay healthy and vibrant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Star Rosette Lichen","description":"Physcia stellaris is a species of lichen. It is pale grey, but darker in the centre, and lacks isidia, lobules, soredia and pruina. It tests negative with potassium hydroxide.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eurasia","North America"],"other_name":["Star Rosette Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Physcia stellaris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15732,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ionactis linariifolia, commonly known as the flaxleaf aster, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. During the growing season, water the plant only when the soil feels dry to the touch, approximately once a week. Be sure to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings, as this plant is susceptible to root rot if left in consistently moist conditions. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture but be cautious not to overwater. In winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters dormancy and requires even less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ionactis linariifolia thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to perform at its best. It can tolerate some light shade, particularly in the afternoon in hotter climates, but optimal growth and flowering occur with ample sunlight. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Therefore, choose a location with plenty of sunlight exposure, and avoid planting it under large trees or structures that may cast significant shade throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ionactis linariifolia is generally minimal, but regular maintenance can promote a bushier habit and improve flowering. Trim back any dead or diseased stems in early spring before new growth begins to maintain plant health. To encourage denser growth, you can pinch back the tips of the stems during the early growing season. After blooming, spent flowers can be deadheaded to prevent the plant from self-seeding and to enhance its appearance. Avoid heavy pruning later in the season, as this can stress the plant before winter dormancy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Flax-leaved Aster","description":"Ionactis linariifolia also known as the flax-leaf ankle-aster, flaxleaf whitetop or simply aster is a North American species of plants in the daisy family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Canada"],"other_name":["Flax-leaved Aster"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Ionactis linariifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It prefers moist, well-drained soil but is quite adaptable once established. Regular watering is essential during the first few years until the tree develops a deep root system, especially during dry spells. Mature trees can tolerate some drought but will benefit from occasional deep watering in prolonged dry periods. Avoid excessive watering, as overly soggy soil can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and protect the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus imbricaria thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure robust growth. It can tolerate partial shade, but less sunlight may lead to reduced growth and a sparser canopy. Planting in an area that receives full sun not only supports optimal growth but also enhances the fall color display, for which this tree is prized. Despite its adaptability, providing ample sunlight will ensure that the Shingle Oak develops into a healthy, strong tree with its characteristic dense and broad canopy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for the Quercus imbricaria should primarily be done to remove dead or damaged branches to improve its health and shape. Light pruning can be done in the dormant season, typically late winter to early spring, before new growth begins. This helps the tree recover quickly. Avoid heavy pruning as it may stress the tree, especially mature specimens. Suckers and water sprouts should be cut back to the branch collar to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage a strong structure. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"shingle oak","description":"Quercus imbricaria, the shingle oak, is a deciduous tree in the red oak group of oaks. It is native primarily to the Midwestern and Upper South regions of North America, from southern New York west to northern Illinois and eastern Kansas, and south to central Alabama and Arkansas. It is most commonly found growing in uplands with good drainage, less often along lowland streams, at 100–700 m altitude.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["shingle oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Canker"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus imbricaria"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

English common names include cloudberry, bakeapple (in Newfoundland and Labrador), knotberry and knoutberry (in England), aqpik or low-bush salmonberry (in Alaska - not to be confused with true salmonberry, Rubus spectabilis), and averin or evron (in Scotland).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Northern Hemisphere","Arctic Tundra","Boreal Forests"],"other_name":["cloudberry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Rubus chamaemorus"],"soil":["Acidic","Peaty","Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14938,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Heuchera americana, commonly known as coral bells or alumroot, prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. It is important to water this plant regularly, especially during dry spells, but avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot. During the growing season, aim to keep the soil evenly moist. In winter, reduce watering to prevent waterlogged soil, which the plant does not tolerate well. Young plants or recently transplanted ones may need more frequent watering until they are established, typically for the first year, to ensure good root development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Heuchera americana thrives in partial sun to partial shade. It is particularly well-suited for environments that receive morning sunlight but are shaded from the harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch the leaves. In regions with hotter climates, more shade throughout the day may be necessary to protect the plant. Conversely, in cooler climates, it can tolerate more direct sunlight. Adaptability to different light conditions means it can also grow in full shade, though flowering might be less prolific, and foliage colors may not be as vibrant as when some sunlight is present."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Heuchera americana involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance and health. This can be done throughout the growing season. In late autumn, after the first frost, cut back the dead foliage close to the ground. This helps prevent any potential diseases from overwintering. As the season progresses, you can remove spent flower stalks to encourage further blooming and improve the plant's appearance. Regularly removing old leaves also encourages fresh growth and improves air circulation around the plant, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American alumroot","description":"Heuchera americana, or American alumroot, is a small (under 2 ft. high and wide) evergreen perennial native to eastern and central North America in the Saxifrage family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish-white","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green, Purple"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["American alumroot"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew","Root rot","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Heuchera americana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14738,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Prunus caroliniana, commonly known as the Carolina Laurel Cherry, prefers well-drained soil and needs regular watering during its establishment period, generally the first year after planting. Once established, it possesses a good drought tolerance and requires less frequent watering. During extended periods of drought, however, it will benefit from occasional deep watering to ensure its long-term health and robustness. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot; allowing the soil to dry between watering is advisable. Mulching around the base can help maintain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus caroliniana thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It can tolerate a range of sunlight conditions but performs optimally with at least four to six hours of direct sunlight daily. In regions with extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Adequate sunlight will ensure vigorous growth and denser foliage, which is ideal if the plant is used as a hedge or screen. While it can manage in shadier spots, expect slower growth and a potentially sparser appearance with less flowering if it doesn't receive sufficient light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning is not necessary for Prunus caroliniana unless you want to maintain a specific shape or size. Pruning can be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to promote healthy growth and increase air circulation. Pruning can also stimulate denser foliage if you desire a more compact form. If grown as a hedge, you may wish to trim it a few times per year to maintain a formal shape. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and avoid spreading diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Carolina laurelcherry","description":"Prunus caroliniana, known as the Carolina laurelcherry, Carolina cherry laurel, cherry laurel, or Carolina cherry, is a small evergreen flowering tree native to the lowlands of Southeastern United States, from North Carolina south to Florida and westward to central Texas. It will bloom more profusely in full sun; however, in hotter climates, some afternoon shade is beneficial to protect it from excessive heat. Ensure the plant receives at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering, but avoid placing it in full, harsh sun in warm climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Daphne mezereum should be done with care, mainly to shape the plant and remove any dead or damaged branches. The best time to prune is right after flowering in late spring. This timing helps to avoid cutting off next year's flower buds, as the plant blooms on old wood. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts. Avoid heavy pruning, as daphnes can be sensitive and may not respond well to harsh treatment. Focus on maintaining its natural shape and removing any crossing or congested growth to improve air circulation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mezereon","description":"Daphne mezereum, commonly known as mezereum, mezereon, February daphne, spurge laurel or spurge olive, is a species of Daphne in the flowering plant family Thymelaeaceae, native to most of Europe and Western Asia, north to northern Scandinavia and Russia. In southern Europe it is confined to medium to higher elevations and in the subalpine vegetation zone, but descends to near sea level in northern Europe. It is generally confined to soils derived from limestone.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Northern Asia"],"other_name":["Mezereon"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Daphne mezereum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to bloom profusely. While it can tolerate some partial shade, too much shade can lead to weaker growth and fewer flowers. Consider the local climate when situating the plant to ensure it receives adequate light without excessive heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solidago ptarmicoides helps maintain its shape and encourages more blooms. After the plant has finished blooming in the fall, cut back the stems to about 6 inches above the ground. This will help the plant conserve energy during winter and promote robust growth in spring. If the plant becomes too tall or leggy during the growing season, it can be trimmed lightly to maintain its form. Deadheading (removing spent flowers) during the blooming season can encourage additional flowering. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"white flat-topped goldenrod","description":"Solidago ptarmicoides, the prairie goldenrod, white flat-top goldenrod or upland white aster a North American species of goldenrod in the sunflower family. Ideally, maintain the plant in a shaded area of a garden or use artificial grow lights set to a low intensity to mimic natural light cycles, supporting robust and healthy growth without dehydration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is typically not necessary for fungi like Kuehneromyces mutabilis. Instead, focus on harvesting. When the mushrooms are fully mature, they can be gently twisted and pulled from the substrate to avoid damaging the mycelium. Regularly inspect the growing areas to remove any decaying material or competing fungi to prevent contamination and support healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sheathed Woodtuft","description":"Kuehneromyces mutabilis (synonym: Pholiota mutabilis), commonly known as the sheathed woodtuft, is an edible mushroom that grows in clumps on tree stumps or other dead wood. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15336,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ipomoea sagittata, commonly known as the saltmarsh morning-glory, thrives in environments that mimic its natural coastal and marshy habitats. This plant prefers moderate watering. Allow the soil to dry slightly between watering, ensuring that the plant is not sitting in waterlogged conditions, as this can lead to root rot. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water more frequently to keep the soil consistently moist (but not soggy). In contrast, reduce watering during the dormant winter months, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out completely before re-watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ipomoea sagittata thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sun per day for optimal growth and flowering. In its native habitat, it naturally grows in open, sun-bathed areas, which makes high-light conditions crucial for its development. If grown indoors or in regions with limited sunlight, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights to ensure it receives enough light. Too much shade can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. Thus, placing this plant in a bright, sunny spot will help it to flourish and produce its vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ipomoea sagittata is beneficial to control its vigorous growth habit and to promote a more bushy appearance. Prune in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems, encouraging healthy new growth. Regular trimming of the long, trailing vines during the growing season helps maintain the desired shape and prevents the plant from becoming unmanageable. Additionally, pinching back young shoots can promote branching. Be careful not to prune too heavily in one session, as this can stress the plant. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Saltmarsh Morning-glory","description":"Ipomoea sagittata, commonly called the saltmarsh morning glory, is a species of flowering plant in the morning glory family. It is native to the Caribbean, Mexico, and the Southeastern United States where it is found in coastal areas. Its natural habitats are thickets on barrier islands, the edges of salt marshes, and in hammocks....","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Mexico","Central America","Caribbean"],"other_name":["Saltmarsh Morning-glory"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Ipomoea sagittata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14837,"attracts":["Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Viburnum carlesii, known commonly as the Korean spice viburnum, prefers regular watering, especially during its first few years to establish a deep root system. Once established, it is relatively drought-tolerant but benefits from consistent moisture in the soil. Water the plant deeply once a week during dry spells, ensuring the soil is moist but not soggy. It's important to allow the top inch or so of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Mulching can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature, which is beneficial for this shrub's overall health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Korean spice viburnum thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal flowering and growth, it is best planted in a location where it can receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In areas with very hot summers, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. In shadier conditions, the shrub will still grow, but flowering may be reduced. Ensure it has access to a good amount of sunlight to enjoy its fragrant, pinkish-white spring blooms and vibrant fall colors."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Viburnum carlesii should be done immediately after flowering to avoid cutting off next year's blooms. Remove any dead or diseased wood first, and then thin out the plant by cutting back overgrown branches to encourage a more open structure and better air circulation. You can lightly shape the bush to maintain its form. Avoid heavy pruning as it can diminish the shrub's flowering potential the following spring. Regular pruning helps to maintain its size and promotes healthier growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Korean Spice Viburnum","description":"Viburnum carlesii (common names arrowwood, Korean spice viburnum,) is a species of flowering plant in the family Adoxaceae (formerly Caprifoliaceae), native to Korea and Japan (Tsushima Island). Growing to 2 m (7 ft) tall and broad, it is a bushy deciduous shrub with oval leaves which are copper-coloured when young. Round clusters of red buds open to strongly scented, pale pink flowers in late spring. These are followed in late summer by oval red fruits ripening to black...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Korea"],"other_name":["Korean Spice Viburnum"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Viburnum carlesii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14341,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lobelia pinifolia requires consistent moisture for healthy growth, but it needs good drainage to prevent root rot. Water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil is kept evenly moist but not waterlogged. It’s better to water thoroughly less frequently than to give a little water often. During hot or dry periods, increase watering frequency, but ensure any excess water can drain away. If the plant is in a container, check that the pot has drainage holes to prevent standing water, which can harm the roots. Reduce watering during cooler months as the plant's need for moisture decreases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lobelia pinifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal flowering, provide it with at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day. Too little sunlight can result in leggy growth and fewer blooms, while too much intense sunlight in very hot climates may stress the plant. Morning sun with afternoon shade is often ideal, especially in hotter regions. If the plant is placed indoors, a bright location near a window with filtered sunlight is beneficial. Adjust the plant’s location as needed if it shows signs of too much or too little sun, such as yellowing leaves or reduced flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lobelia pinifolia helps promote bushier growth and more abundant flowering. Trim the plant back after the main flowering season to encourage new growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or wilted stems and leaves regularly to maintain plant health and appearance. Pinching back the stems can encourage more blooms and prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. Be cautious not to over-prune as this can reduce blooming potential. In spring, a more substantial cutback may be useful if the plant has become too unruly, allowing it to regenerate and grow more compactly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pineleaf Lobelia","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Pineleaf Lobelia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Lobelia pinifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important not to let the soil completely dry out, especially during dry spells. Regular watering is essential, particularly in the hotter months to maintain soil moisture without waterlogging. In cooler weather, watering can be reduced. It's beneficial to water early in the day to allow foliage to dry out, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. A layer of organic mulch can also help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature, but ensure not to cover the plant's crown to prevent rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leucothoe axillaris thrives in partial shade to full shade environments. It can tolerate some morning sun, but it's best protected from the harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch its leaves or make them more susceptible to pests and diseases. If planted in full shade, it may have slower growth or produce fewer flowers, but it will maintain healthy, green foliage. When planting, consider a location that offers filtered or dappled sunlight throughout the day. Adjust exposure based on climate; in cooler regions, slightly more sun can be tolerated."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Leucothoe axillaris is mainly done to maintain its shape and health. The best time to prune is in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches to improve air circulation and overall appearance. Light pruning can help maintain a neat shape, though heavy pruning may reduce flowering. It's also beneficial to remove any crossing or overcrowded branches to allow sunlight to penetrate the interior, reducing the risk of disease. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Swamp Dog-laurel","description":"Leucothoe axillaris is a shrub native to the southeastern United States, with the common names swamp dog-laurel and coastal dog-hobble. It grows on floodplains in coastal areas at elevations of less than 200 me (670 feet).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Swamp Dog-laurel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Leucothoe axillaris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15037,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia verticillata, commonly known as whorled clary, prefers consistent watering, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. Water the plant deeply but let the soil dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. During the cooler months, reduce watering frequency as the plant requires less moisture. A well-draining soil helps maintain the right balance of moisture, preventing the roots from becoming waterlogged. It's crucial to ensure that the plant doesn’t sit in water for extended periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia verticillata thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to produce an abundant display of flowers. In regions with particularly hot summers, providing some afternoon shade might benefit the plant by preventing leaf scorch. While it can tolerate some shade, too little light may result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. Planting in a location with good air circulation and adequate sunlight exposure will contribute to its optimal growth and vibrant blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia verticillata is beneficial for promoting healthier growth and maintaining its shape. It's ideal to prune after the plant has finished its blooming period, typically in late summer or early fall. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp tools to make smooth cuts and minimize stress on the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"river birch","description":"Betula nigra (black birch, river birch, water birch) is a species of birch native to the Eastern United States from New Hampshire west to southern Minnesota, and south to northern Florida and west to Texas. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water the plant frequently, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Reduce watering in fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down. It's important to use well-draining soil to prevent root rot, as the curry leaf plant does not tolerate soggy conditions. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced leaf production. In extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even exposure to sunlight on all sides."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Murraya koenigii is essential to encourage bushier growth and maintain its shape. Trim the plant in late winter or early spring before the growing season starts. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches, as well as any branches that cross and potentially damage each other. Pruning can also involve cutting back long, leggy growth to promote lateral branching and denser foliage. Regularly pinching off the tips of the branches can also help in maintaining a compact shape. This plant is native to open, sunny environments, and thus performs better with ample sunlight, promoting strong growth and vibrant flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Penstemon fruticosus in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems that did not survive the winter. This will encourage new growth and a bushier plant. After blooming, you can deadhead the spent flowers to encourage further flowering and maintain a tidy appearance. Cut the stems back by about a third to invigorate the plant and promote better branching. Avoid heavy pruning in late fall, as this can leave the penstemon vulnerable to winter damage due to open cuts on the plant stems."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bush Penstemon","description":"Penstemon fruticosus is a species of penstemon known by the common names bush penstemon or shrubby penstemon. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14838,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Magnolia stellata requires consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. It's essential to water the plant regularly during its growing season, especially in dry periods. Ensure the top layer of soil is dry before re-watering to avoid overwatering. The soil should remain consistently moist in the spring and summer. Reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant is not actively growing. Applying mulch around the base can help retain soil moisture. Always plant in well-draining soil to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Magnolia stellata thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal flowering and growth, provide at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. Too much shade may lead to reduced blooming, so finding a balanced location is key. Ensure the plant receives ample direct morning sunlight but is protected from the harsh afternoon sun. Consistent, moderate sunlight will encourage a healthy, flourishing magnolia."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Magnolia stellata should be performed in late winter or early spring before active growth begins. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain plant health and improve airflow. Additionally, thin out congested areas to shape the tree and prevent branch overlap. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant; light trimming is preferred. Refrain from pruning once flower buds have formed, as this can reduce flowering for the season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"star magnolia","description":"Magnolia stellata, sometimes called the star magnolia, is a slow-growing shrub or small tree native to Japan. It bears large, showy white or pink flowers in early spring, before its leaves open. This species is closely related to the Kobushi magnolia (Magnolia kobus), and is treated by many botanists as a variety or even a cultivar of that. However, Magnolia stellata was accepted as a distinct species in the 1998 monograph by Hunt.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Japan"],"other_name":["star magnolia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Magnolia stellata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Planting it in a south or west-facing location is ideal to ensure it gets the necessary amount of sunlight for optimal vigor and bloom production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Anisacanthus quadrifidus is essential for encouraging new growth and maintaining its shape. Perform a hard prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back the stems to 6-12 inches above the ground to promote dense, bushy growth in the upcoming growing season. Throughout the season, remove any dead or damaged branches to improve air circulation. Light trimming during the growing season can also stimulate blooms and keep the plant tidy. Avoid heavy pruning in late summer or fall, as it may affect the next year's flowering."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Flame acanthus","description":"Anisacanthus quadrifidus is a species of flowering plant native to west and south-central Texas in the United States and adjacent northern Mexico down through the state of Oaxaca. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15039,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia reflexa, commonly known as lanceleaf sage, is a drought-tolerant plant once established and prefers infrequent, deep watering. Allow the topsoil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot and overly moist conditions which can harm the plant. During the growing season, it might require more frequent watering, approximately once a week. However, in the cooler months, reduce watering substantially. Always ensure good drainage by planting in well-draining soil or using pots with drainage holes to prevent water accumulation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia reflexa thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. It can tolerate partial shade, but this might reduce the number of blooms and result in leggier growth. When planting outdoors, consider a location that receives plenty of morning sun and some afternoon shade in hotter climates to protect the plant from extreme temperatures. Indoors, place the pot near a sunny window, preferably a south or west-facing one, to ensure it receives adequate light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia reflexa involves cutting back the plant to encourage bushiness and remove spent flowers. After the flowering period, prune the plant by cutting back the flower stalks to the base and trimming any dead or damaged leaves. This not only promotes a tidier appearance but also encourages subsequent blooms. Deadheading throughout the flowering season can also extend the blooming period by preventing seed formation. Winter or early spring is an ideal time for more extensive pruning, where you can cut back one-third of the plant to refresh its growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mintweed","description":"Salvia reflexa, the lanceleaf sage, Rocky Mountain sage, blue sage, lambsleaf sage, sage mint or mintweed, is a perennial subshrub native to the United States and Mexico and introduced to Argentina, Australia, Canada, South Africa and New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Mintweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Salvia reflexa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14147,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euonymus atropurpureus, commonly known as Eastern Wahoo, prefers moderate watering conditions. Water the plant deeply when the soil feels dry to the touch, particularly during its active growth period in spring and summer. Reduce watering frequency in the fall and winter when the plant is dormant. Ensure proper drainage to prevent root rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and provide temperature regulation. Be attentive to your local weather conditions, adjusting your watering routine accordingly to maintain optimal moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euonymus atropurpureus thrives best in partial to full sunlight. It can tolerate a range of light conditions, but for optimal growth and fruit production, provide it with at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Planting in an area where it can receive morning sun with afternoon shade can be ideal. This adaptability makes it suitable for use in a variety of landscape settings, though its preference is for environments where it gets ample but not excessive sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Euonymus atropurpureus should be done during the dormant season, late winter to early spring, before new growth emerges. This helps in shaping the plant, removing dead or damaged branches, and encouraging healthy new growth. Focus on maintaining an open structure to improve air circulation within the plant. Remove any crossing or rubbing branches as these can lead to wounds susceptible to diseases. Light pruning throughout the growing season can help maintain its desired shape. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent injury and the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"wahoo","description":"Euonymus atropurpureus is a species of shrub in the bittersweet family. In winter, reduce the frequency of watering sessions, letting nature's rain take over in areas where it occurs naturally, and step in only if the plant is indoors or in extended dry periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Biscutella laevigata thrives in full sun to partial shade. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15932,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lecanora hybocarpa is a type of lichen, and lichens generally have different water needs compared to typical houseplants. They rely on atmospheric moisture, such as rain or fog, to hydrate. In cultivation, attempt to simulate these conditions by providing occasional misting, especially if they are grown indoors or in dry climates. Be cautious not to overwater, as lichens do not require constant moisture and may be sensitive to excess water, which can promote fungal growth or rot. Ensure they are allowed to dry out thoroughly between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lecanora hybocarpa, like many lichens, usually thrives in indirect sunlight or partial shade. It grows well in environments that offer filtered light, as direct sunlight can be too intense and may dry out or damage the delicate structure of the lichen. When cultivating, try to plant or place it in a spot that mimics its natural environment—typically areas where filtered light through trees or other structures is available for several hours each day. Avoid placing it in deep shade, as lack of light can hinder its growth and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Lichens like Lecanora hybocarpa typically do not require pruning. These symbiotic organisms are slow-growing and adapt to their environment naturally. If you want to shape or control their growth for display purposes, occasionally remove any dead or decaying parts gently by hand without disrupting their substrate attachment. Ensure that any trimming does not harm the lichen's thallus, the main body of the lichen, as this could hinder its growth or cause damage. Regularly check for any signs of infestations or disease and gently remove affected areas if necessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bumpy Rim-lichen","description":"Lecanora hybocarpa is a species of lichen in the family Lecanoraceae. Originally described in 1849 as a species of Parmelia, it was transferred to Lecanora in 1984 by Irwin Brodo.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Bumpy Rim-lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lecanora hybocarpa"],"soil":["Rocky","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14741,"attracts":["Birds","Mammals"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus pubescens, commonly known as the downy oak, is drought-tolerant and has low water requirements once established. It prefers well-draining soil and should be watered deeply but infrequently. During dry spells or extremely hot weather, additional watering may be necessary, especially for younger trees. However, it's important not to overwater, as excess moisture can lead to root rot. Generally, allow the top few inches of soil to dry out between watering sessions. Monitoring the soil moisture and adjusting watering based on the tree's age and local climate conditions will ensure optimal health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus pubescens thrives in full sun and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to grow well. It is well-suited to open landscapes where it can receive unobstructed sunlight. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal growth and acorn production occur with full sun exposure. When planting, choose a location that provides ample sunlight throughout the day to support strong growth and foliage density. In shadier environments, the tree may become leggy, with reduced vigor. Ensure the surrounding area allows for the expansion of its canopy without competition or obstruction from other plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus pubescens should be done carefully to maintain its shape and health. It's best to prune during the dormant season, typically late winter or early spring, to avoid bleeding sap and to encourage vigorous new growth. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to promote airflow and reduce disease risk. Additionally, thin out crowded areas to ensure sunlight reaches the inner parts of the tree. Avoid cutting large branches unless necessary, as this can cause stress to the tree. Prune young trees to establish a strong structure. Make clean cuts at the branch collar to facilitate proper healing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"downy oak","description":"Quercus pubescens, the downy oak or pubescent oak, is a species of white oak (genus Quercus sect. Quercus) native to southern Europe and southwest Asia, from northern Spain (Pyrenees) east to the Crimea and the Caucasus. It is also found in France and parts of central Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southern Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["downy oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Oak gall wasp"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Quercus pubescens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Rocky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Mimic its natural shaded habitat with indirect or filtered light, ensuring enough light for the host plants which indirectly supports the growth of Hyobanche sanguinea. Adjust lighting conditions based on the specific needs of the host plants it’s associated with."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hyobanche sanguinea is generally not necessary due to its parasitic nature and growth habit. Ensure that any dead or decayed parts are also removed to maintain a healthy environment. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14941,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fomes fomentarius, commonly known as the hoof fungus, typically grows on trees and does not require traditional watering like houseplants. If cultivating in a controlled environment or seeking to preserve it, ensure the environment mimics its natural conditions. This would typically mean high humidity levels and a damp, decaying wood substrate. Regular misting might help to maintain moisture if needed, but direct water application is generally unnecessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fomes fomentarius thrives in the natural forest environment, typically in shaded to semi-shaded areas. Direct sunlight is not necessary for its growth, as it is used to the dappled light filtering through a forest canopy. If attempting to grow or store it artificially, providing indirect lighting conditions similar to a shaded forest habitat will be beneficial. It does not require direct sunlight and can be adversely affected by prolonged exposure to direct sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Fomes fomentarius in the traditional sense. Focus on removing crossing branches, as well as any that are inward facing to allow better air circulation within the shrub. Direct sunlight can scorch its leaves, so it's best placed near a window with filtered light. If growing indoors, an east or north-facing window is ideal. In lower light conditions, the plant may experience slower growth, but it can adapt. However, insufficient light over a long period can lead to a sparse appearance. If grown outdoors, ensure that it receives shade during the hottest part of the day. Monitor the plant for signs of sunburn or inadequate light and adjust its position accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pellaea glabella is generally minimal, focusing mainly on removing dead or damaged fronds to keep the plant healthy and attractive. Use a clean pair of scissors or pruning shears to cut fronds at the base, close to the soil. Regularly trimming yellow or brown leaves encourages new growth and prevents potential pest problems. It is best to prune during the plant's active growing season in spring and summer. Avoid heavy pruning, as this plant does not respond well to aggressive cutting."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"smooth cliffbrake","description":"Pellaea glabella is the smooth cliffbrake. For much of pteridological history, it was regarded as a reduced form or variety of Pellaea atropurpurea. P. glabella is known to exist in two cryptic species, one diploid and one tetraploid. The diploid reproduces sexually, while the tetraploid is normally apogamous. It is now known that the tetraploid form of the species is one of the parents of the original hybrid P. Xatropurpurea that became the apogamous species.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["smooth cliffbrake"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pellaea glabella"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14344,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Serruria glomerata, often called the Spiderhead, prefers well-draining soil, so watering should be moderate. Ensure that the soil is allowed to dry out somewhat between waterings to prevent root rot. During the hotter months, you may need to water more frequently, possibly once a week, depending on the climate, ensuring the top soil layer is dry before the next watering. In cooler months, reduce the frequency. It’s crucial to avoid overhead watering, which can encourage fungal diseases. Instead, water at the base of the plant early in the morning, allowing moisture to evaporate during the day."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Serruria glomerata thrives in full sun to light shade. It requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can protect it from extreme temperatures. However, too much shade can lead to leggy growth and fewer flowers. When planting in a garden, choose a spot that receives morning sunlight and some afternoon shade if possible. In indoor settings, a bright window with plenty of indirect light is ideal, but occasional exposure to direct sunlight will benefit the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Serruria glomerata is important to maintain its shape and encourage bushiness. The best time to prune this plant is after it has finished flowering. Remove spent flower heads and any dead or diseased stems. Lightly prune any leggy or unruly branches to encourage a more compact form. Avoid heavy pruning into old wood as this may not regenerate. Regular deadheading during the flowering season will also encourage more blooms. Always use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to minimize the risk of infection or disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cluster Spiderhead","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Cream","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Cluster Spiderhead"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Serruria glomerata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14942,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ficus religiosa, commonly known as the Sacred Fig, requires moderate watering. It's important to allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings; this can help prevent root rot and over-watering issues. The plant prefers consistent moisture during the growing season (spring and summer) but should be watered sparingly in the colder months. Always ensure proper drainage to avoid water accumulation in the pot. Keep an eye on the leaf condition; if they start drooping, it may be a sign the plant needs water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ficus religiosa thrives in full to partial sunlight. It prefers a spot where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily, which is crucial for healthy growth and robust foliage. However, if you're growing this plant indoors, place it near a bright window where it can absorb ample natural light, avoiding shaded or low-light areas. If exposed to too much harsh sunlight, especially in the afternoon, the leaves may scorch, so filtered light might be beneficial during peak sun intensity. Adjust light exposure based on plant response."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ficus religiosa is essential to maintain its shape and remove any dead or unhealthy branches. The best time to prune is during the growth period, typically in spring. Use clean, sharp shears to make cuts at a 45-degree angle. Focus on removing branches that cross each other or grow towards the interior of the plant, as well as any that are damaged or diseased. Regular pruning also encourages bushier growth and can prevent the plant from becoming too large or leggy. Be cautious of the plant's milky sap, which can irritate the skin."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sacred fig","description":"Ficus religiosa or sacred fig is a species of fig native to the Indian subcontinent, and Indochina. It belongs to the Moraceae, the fig or mulberry family. It is also known as the bodhi tree, pippala tree, peepul tree, peepal tree or ashwattha tree (in India and Nepal).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["India","Nepal","Sri Lanka","Southwest China","Indochina"],"other_name":["Sacred fig"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ficus religiosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16025,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Anomodon attenuatus, a type of moss, generally requires a consistently moist environment to thrive. It is important to ensure that the substrate it grows on remains damp, simulating its natural habitat. However, avoid waterlogging as excessive water can lead to fungal problems. Misting the moss regularly can suffice, and using distilled or rainwater can prevent mineral buildup. Monitoring humidity levels is also beneficial, aiming for a relatively high humidity environment. If indoors, placing a humidity tray or using a humidifier might be necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Anomodon attenuatus moss prefers a location with low to moderate indirect light, as direct sunlight can be too harsh and drying for the plant. In its natural habitat, it typically grows on forest floors or shaded rocks, indicating its preference for dappled or filtered light. When cultivating indoors, placing it near a north or east-facing window with indirect light is ideal. If grown outside, ensure it is in a shaded area to mimic its natural environmental conditions and protect it from direct sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Anomodon attenuatus involves trimming any dead or discolored sections of the moss. Pruning should be done carefully as these mosses have delicate structures. It is beneficial to prune not only for keeping a tidy appearance but also for preventing any possible decay that could affect the entire plant. Use small, sharp scissors or gardening shears to remove unwanted parts. Perform pruning as needed, usually during the growing season when the plant is actively growing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Anomodon Moss","description":"Anomodon attenuatus, commonly known as anomodon moss, is a species of moss in the family Thuidiaceae. It has a wide-ranging distribution and can be found from Canada to Central America and the Caribbean as well as in Europe and Asia (India, eastern Russia, and Turkey).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Anomodon Moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Anomodon attenuatus"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
